u.txt: It was from my own Elizabeth:—<p
of dear kind Henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account. You are forbidden to write—to hold a pen; yet one word from you
I have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have restrained my uncle

I have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have I regretted not being able to perform it myself! I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with
care and affection of your poor cousin. Yet that is over now:
>“Get well—and return to us. You will find a happy, cheerful home, and friends who love you dearly
asks but to see you,—but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance. How pleased
be to remark the improvement of our Ernest! He
full of activity and spirit. He
desirous to be a true Swiss,
to enter into foreign service; but we cannot part with him, at least until his elder brother return to us
is not pleased with the idea of a military career in a distant country; but
application. He looks upon study as an odious fetter;—his time
will become an idler, unless we yield
point, and permit him to enter on
Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. The blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and

think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. My trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and I am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. Since
left us, but one change has taken place in our
but my anxiety returns upon me as I conclude
—one line—one word will be a blessing to us. Ten thousand thanks to Henry for his kindness, his affection, and his many letters: we
sincerely grateful. Adieu! my cousin; take care of yourself; and, I entreat you
It was from my own Elizabeth:—<p
of dear kind Henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account. You are forbidden to write—to hold a pen; yet one word from you
I have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have restrained my uncle

I have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have I regretted not being able to perform it myself! I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with
care and affection of your poor cousin. Yet that is over now:
>“Get well—and return to us. You will find a happy, cheerful home, and friends who love you dearly
asks but to see you,—but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance. How pleased
be to remark the improvement of our Ernest! He
full of activity and spirit. He
desirous to be a true Swiss,
to enter into foreign service; but we cannot part with him, at least until his elder brother return to us
is not pleased with the idea of a military career in a distant country; but
application. He looks upon study as an odious fetter;—his time
will become an idler, unless we yield
point, and permit him to enter on
Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. The blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and

think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. My trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and I am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. Since
left us, but one change has taken place in our
but my anxiety returns upon me as I conclude
—one line—one word will be a blessing to us. Ten thousand thanks to Henry for his kindness, his affection, and his many letters: we
sincerely grateful. Adieu! my cousin; take care of yourself; and, I entreat you

I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your health. We cannot help imagining that your friend Clerval conceals the extent of your disorder: for it is now several months since we have seen your hand-writing; and all this time you
you must have been exceedingly ill;
this makes us all very wretched, as much so nearly as after the death of your dear mother.
almost persuaded that you were indeed dangerously ill,
; for indeed, indeed, Victor, we are all very miserable on this account. Relieve us from this fear, and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world
that he appears ten years younger since last winter. Ernest also is so much improved, that you would hardly know him: he
has lost that sickly appearance which he had some years ago; he
and I conversed a long time last night about what profession
should follow. His constant illness when young has deprived him of the habits
application; and now that he enjoys good health, he
should be a farmer; which you know,
, is a favourite scheme of mine. A farmer’s is a very healthy happy life; and

most beneficial profession of any. My uncle had an idea of his being educated as an advocate, that through his interest he might become a judge. But, besides that he is not at all fitted for such an occupation, it is certainly more creditable to cultivate the earth for the sustenance of man, than to be the confidant, and sometimes the accomplice, of his vices; which is the profession of a lawyer. I said, that the employments of a prosperous farmer, if they were not a more honourable, they were at least a happier species of occupation than that of a judge, whose misfortune it was always to meddle with the dark side of human nature. My uncle smiled, and said, that I ought to be an advocate myself, which put an end to the conversation on that subject
After what I have said, I dare say you well remember the heroine of my little tale: for Justine
yet I cannot conclude without again anxiously inquiring concerning your health
not very ill, write yourself, and make your father and all of us happy; or——I cannot bear to think of the other side of the question; my tears already flow. Adieu
It was from my own Elizabeth:—<p
of dear kind Henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account. You are forbidden to write—to hold a pen; yet one word from you
I have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have restrained my uncle

I have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have I regretted not being able to perform it myself! I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with
care and affection of your poor cousin. Yet that is over now:
>“Get well—and return to us. You will find a happy, cheerful home, and friends who love you dearly
asks but to see you,—but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance. How pleased
be to remark the improvement of our Ernest! He
full of activity and spirit. He
desirous to be a true Swiss,
to enter into foreign service; but we cannot part with him, at least until his elder brother return to us
is not pleased with the idea of a military career in a distant country; but
application. He looks upon study as an odious fetter;—his time
will become an idler, unless we yield
point, and permit him to enter on
Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. The blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and

think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. My trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and I am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. Since
left us, but one change has taken place in our
but my anxiety returns upon me as I conclude
—one line—one word will be a blessing to us. Ten thousand thanks to Henry for his kindness, his affection, and his many letters: we
sincerely grateful. Adieu! my cousin; take care of yourself; and, I entreat you
then put the following letter into my hands.

I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your health. We cannot help imagining that your friend Clerval conceals the extent of your disorder: for it is now several months since we have seen your hand-writing; and all this time you
you must have been exceedingly ill;
this makes us all very wretched, as much so nearly as after the death of your dear mother.
almost persuaded that you were indeed dangerously ill,
from undertaking a journey to Ingolstadt.
; for indeed, indeed, Victor, we are all very miserable on this account. Relieve us from this fear, and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world
that he appears ten years younger since last winter. Ernest also is so much improved, that you would hardly know him: he
has lost that sickly appearance which he had some years ago; he
and I conversed a long time last night about what profession
should follow. His constant illness when young has deprived him of the habits
application; and now that he enjoys good health, he
or rowing on the lake. I
should be a farmer; which you know,
, is a favourite scheme of mine. A farmer’s is a very healthy happy life; and

most beneficial profession of any. My uncle had an idea of his being educated as an advocate, that through his interest he might become a judge. But, besides that he is not at all fitted for such an occupation, it is certainly more creditable to cultivate the earth for the sustenance of man, than to be the confidant, and sometimes the accomplice, of his vices; which is the profession of a lawyer. I said, that the employments of a prosperous farmer, if they were not a more honourable, they were at least a happier species of occupation than that of a judge, whose misfortune it was always to meddle with the dark side of human nature. My uncle smiled, and said, that I ought to be an advocate myself, which put an end to the conversation on that subject
? Probably you do not; I will relate her history
Justine was the third. This girl had always been the
father; but, through a strange perversity,
treated her very ill. My aunt observed
prevailed on her mother to allow her to live at
house. The republican institutions of our
happier manners than those which prevail in the great monarchies that surround it.
several classes of its inhabitants; and
the lower orders being neither so poor nor so
Geneva does not mean the same thing as a servant in France
and England. Justine, thus received in
the idea of ignorance, and a sacrifice
After what I have said, I dare say you well remember the heroine of my little tale: for Justine
for the same reason that Ariosto
attachment for her, by which she was induced
education superior to that which she had at first intended
Justine was the most grateful little creature in the
I do not mean that she made any
but you could see by her
that she almost adored her protectress. Although
gay, and in many respects inconsiderate, yet she paid the greatest attention to every gesture of my
every one was too much occupied in their own
who had attended her during her
with the exception of her neglected
left childless. The conscience of the woman was
she began to think that the deaths of her favourites was a
Justine was called home by her repentant
she wept when she quitted our
she was much altered since the death of my
and a winning mildness to her
which had before been remarkable for vivacity. Nor
house of a nature to restore her gaiety. The poor
was very vacillating in her repentance. She sometimes begged Justine to forgive her
into a decline, which at first
died on the first approach of cold
and I assure you I love her tenderly. She is very clever and
continually remind me of my dear
, of little darling William. I wish you could see
. He has already had one or two little
a pretty little girl of five years
you wish to be indulged in a little gossip
concerning the good people of Geneva
the congratulatory visits on her approaching marriage with a young Englishman, John
since the departure of Clerval from
be on the point of marrying a very lively pretty
yet I cannot conclude without again anxiously inquiring concerning your health
not very ill, write yourself, and make your father and all of us happy; or——I cannot bear to think of the other side of the question; my tears already flow. Adieu

<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_del1"/> and this suspicion fills us with anguish. I perceive that your father <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_add1_del1"/>conceals<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_add1_del1"/> attempts to conceal his fears from me; but cheerfulness has flown from our little circle, only to be restored by a certain assuranance that there is no foundation for

I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your health. We cannot help imagining that your friend Clerval conceals the extent of your disorder: for it is now several months since we have seen your hand-writing; and all this time you
you must have been exceedingly ill;
this makes us all very wretched, as much so nearly as after the death of your dear mother.

<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_del1"/> and this suspicion fills us with anguish. I perceive that your father <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_add1_del1"/>conceals<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_add1_del1"/> attempts to conceal his fears from me; but cheerfulness has flown from our little circle, only to be restored by a certain assuranance that there is no foundation for
almost persuaded that you were indeed dangerously ill,
; for indeed, indeed, Victor, we are all very miserable on this account. Relieve us from this fear, and we shall be the happiest creatures in the world
that he appears ten years younger since last winter. Ernest also is so much improved, that you would hardly know him: he
has lost that sickly appearance which he had some years ago; he
and I conversed a long time last night about what profession
should follow. His constant illness when young has deprived him of the habits
application; and now that he enjoys good health, he
should be a farmer; which you know,
, is a favourite scheme of mine. A farmer’s is a very healthy happy life; and

most beneficial profession of any. My uncle had an idea of his being educated as an advocate, that through his interest he might become a judge. But, besides that he is not at all fitted for such an occupation, it is certainly more creditable to cultivate the earth for the sustenance of man, than to be the confidant, and sometimes the accomplice, of his vices; which is the profession of a lawyer. I said, that the employments of a prosperous farmer, if they were not a more honourable, they were at least a happier species of occupation than that of a judge, whose misfortune it was always to meddle with the dark side of human nature. My uncle smiled, and said, that I ought to be an advocate myself, which put an end to the conversation on that subject
After what I have said, I dare say you well remember the heroine of my little tale: for Justine
yet I cannot conclude without again anxiously inquiring concerning your health
not very ill, write yourself, and make your father and all of us happy; or——I cannot bear to think of the other side of the question; my tears already flow. Adieu
><!--2018-04-25 ebb: This collation unit is identical to the 1818 text (no changes in Thomas copy here).--><

then put the following letter into my hands.
It was from my own Elizabeth:—<p

you must have been exceedingly ill;

<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter5_div4_div5_p3_del1"/> and this suspicion fills us with anguish. I have thought that each post would bring this line, and my persuasions have restrained my uncle
could hardly be re st rained
from undertaking a journey to Ingolstadt.

I have prevented his encountering the inconveniences and perhaps dangers of so long a journey; yet how often have I regretted not being able to perform it myself! I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sick bed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes, nor minister to them with

most beneficial profession of any. My uncle had an idea of his being educated as an advocate, that through his interest he might become a judge. But, besides that he is not at all fitted for such an occupation, it is certainly more creditable to cultivate the earth for the sustenance of man, than to be the confidant, and sometimes the accomplice, of his vices; which is the profession of a lawyer. I said, that the employments of a prosperous farmer, if they were not a more honourable, they were at least a happier species of occupation than that of a judge, whose misfortune it was always to meddle with the dark side of human nature. My uncle smiled, and said, that I ought to be an advocate myself, which put an end to the conversation on that subject
Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us. The blue lake, and snow-clad mountains, they never change;—and

think our placid home, and our contented hearts are regulated by the same immutable laws. My trifling occupations take up my time and amuse me, and I am rewarded for any exertions by seeing none but happy, kind faces around me. Since

Cousin yet I can not conclude without again anxiously enquiring concerning your health— Dear Victor, if you are not very ill write yourself and make your father and all of us happy or— I cannot bear to think on the other side of the question my tears <w ana="start"/>already<w ana="end"/> flow Your very affectionate Cousin <del rend="strikethrough" sID="c56-0064__main__d2e13594"/>dearrest<del eID="c56-0064__main__d2e13594"/> –
—one line—one word will be a blessing to us. Ten thousand thanks to Henry for his kindness, his affection, and his many letters: we
